brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to assess how clinicians apply national UK guidance in the assessment of febrile infants presenting the the Emergency Department. The measurable outcomes are:
Primary Objective Compliance with current National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence Guidance (Feverish Illness in the Under 5s)
Report the rates of serious and invasive bacterial infections in febrile infants
Secondary Objectives Report on the predictive value of different clinical features for predicting bacterial infections.
Report on the value of biomarkers for predicting serious and invasive bacterial infections.
Assess the performance of other clinical practice guidelines for the assessment of febrile infants.
Complete a cost evaluation to report the cost of current care per patient

detailed_description.textblock:
The assessment of febrile infants is difficult. In the UK current guidance advocates that most children under 3 months of age with a fever undergo a full septic screen including lumbar puncture and receive parenteral antibiotics. Approaches in the United States and Europe including the Rochester and StepByStep approach allow for the discharge home of some low risk young infants.
We intend to assess the current approach to febrile infants and compare that to the national standard. We also intend to retrospectively assess if alternate approaches (e.g. Rochester) could have been safely applied to that population and to determine which clinical and/or laboratory features are most predictive of serious/invasive bacterial infection.

primary_outcome.description: Invasive Bacterial Infection (non-contaminant) confirmed by culture or molecular diagnostic testing of a sterile site i.e. blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Staphylococcus epidermidis, Propionibacterium acnes, Streptococcus viridans, or Diphtheroides were considered contaminants.

arm_group.description: All infants aged 0-90 days (inclusive) undergoing routine assessments for fever without source.

study_pop.textblock: Infants aged 0-90 days (inclusive) with a fever of 38 degrees centigrade or higher recorded on arrival to hospital between the 01/09/2018 and the 31/08/2019. Conducted across four sites in the UK (all large tertiary children's hospitals).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any infant aged 0 to 90 days (inclusive) with a fever of 38 degrees centigrade or higher recorded on arrival to hospital.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Clear focus for infection on initial assessment
